claims.claim: Intratumoral mRNA vaccination creates an interferon-rich inflammatory state that improves sensitivity to anti-PD-L1 therapy.

evidence.quote: The paper investigates whether intratumoral delivery of an mRNA vaccine can create an interferon-rich inflammatory state that improves sensitivity to anti-PD-L1 therapy.
Type I interferon response score (normalized units): 3.1
PD-L1 expression fold-change in tumor tissue: 2.4x

claims.caveat: Some mechanistic readouts were strongest in specific model systems rather than uniformly across all tested settings.

claims.claim: mRNA vaccination leads to broader antigen display through expansion of the MHC-I-presented peptide repertoire.

evidence.quote: A broader peptide repertoire appears on MHC-I, improving tumor visibility to T cells.
Fraction of tumor proteins represented in immunopeptidome: 62.3%
Fraction of proteins represented in MHC-I peptidome: 40.6%

claims.caveat: Results may vary depending on the specific tumor model system used.

claims.claim: Type I interferon signaling is necessary for the observed tumor sensitization effect.

evidence.quote: Blocking type I interferon signaling with anti-IFNAR1 eliminated the observed sensitization benefit.
Intratumoral mRNA vaccination triggers local innate sensing and type I interferon signaling.

claims.caveat: Experiments were conducted in controlled preclinical models and may not fully capture human tumor heterogeneity.

claims.claim: Prior SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccination is associated with improved survival in metastatic patients receiving ICI treatment.

evidence.quote: Retrospective human survival comparison p-value: p=0.01
aligns with better outcomes in the retrospective human cohort

claims.caveat: The human analysis is retrospective and non-randomized; residual confounding is likely and vaccination timing relative to ICI initiation varied across patients.
